markdownRemark.html:
Table of Contents

  • Time-evolution operator
  • Superposition of energy eigenstates
  • Time evolution of superposed bound state SW

- Time-evolution operator

Time-evolution operator 𝑈(𝑡)

∣ψ(t)⟩=U^(t)∣ψ(0)⟩|\psi(t)\rangle=\widehat{U}(t)|\psi(0)\rangle∣ψ(t)⟩=U(t)∣ψ(0)⟩

U^(t)\widehat{U}(t)U(t) is Hermitian operator.

In order for probability to be conserved as time evolves,

⟨ψ(t)∣ψ(t)⟩=⟨ψ(0)∣U^†(t)U^(t)∣ψ(0)⟩=⟨ψ(0)∣ψ(0)⟩\begin{aligned}\langle\psi(t) | \psi(t)\rangle &=\left\langle\psi(0)\left|\widehat{U}^{\dagger}(t) \widehat{U}(t)\right| \psi(0)\right\rangle \\ &=\langle\psi(0) | \psi(0)\rangle \end{aligned}⟨ψ(t)∣ψ(t)⟩​=⟨ψ(0)∣∣∣​U†(t)U(t)∣∣∣​ψ(0)⟩=⟨ψ(0)∣ψ(0)⟩​

And consequently the operator U^(t)\widehat{U}(t)U(t) must be unitary:

U^†(t)U^(t)=1\widehat{U}^{\dagger}(t) \widehat{U}(t)=1U†(t)U(t)=1

The Hamiltonian H^\widehat{H}H, the energy operator, enters as the generator of time translations through the infinitesimal time-evolution operator:

U^(dt)=1−iℏH^dt\widehat{U}(d t)=1-\frac{i}{\hbar} \widehat{H} d tU(dt)=1−ℏi​Hdt

The time-evolution operator obeys the differential equation

H^(t)U^(t)=iℏddtU^(t)\hat{H}(t) \widehat{U}(t)=i \hbar \frac{d}{d t} \widehat{U}(t)H^(t)U(t)=iℏdtd​U(t)

leading to the Schrodinger equation:

H^∣ψ(t)⟩=iℏddt∣ψ(t)⟩\widehat{H}|\psi(t)\rangle= i \hbar \frac{d}{d t}|\psi(t)\rangleH∣ψ(t)⟩=iℏdtd​∣ψ(t)⟩

A particularly useful solution to (*) occurs when the Hamiltonian is independent of time, in which case the time-development operator is given by

U^(t)=e−iEt/ℏ\widehat{U}(t)=e^{-i E t / \hbar}U(t)=e−iEt/ℏ

The action of the time-development operator on an energy eigenstate ∣E⟩|E\rangle∣E⟩ is given by

e−iH^t/ℏ∣E⟩=e−iEt/ℏ∣E⟩e^{-i \hat{H} t / \hbar}|E\rangle= e^{-i E t / \hbar}|E\ranglee−iH^t/ℏ∣E⟩=e−iEt/ℏ∣E⟩

Showing that a single energy eigenstate just picks up an overall phase as time evolves and is therefore a stationary state.

Superposition of energy eigenstates

  • Time evolution for a state operator ∣ψ(t)⟩|\psi(t)\rangle∣ψ(t)⟩
∣ψ(0)⟩=∑n∣En⟩⟨En∣ψ(0)⟩|\psi(0)\rangle=\sum_{n}\left|E_{n}\right\rangle\left\langle E_{n} | \psi(0)\right\rangle∣ψ(0)⟩=n∑​∣En​⟩⟨En​∣ψ(0)⟩

is given by

∣ψ(t)⟩=e−iB^t/ℏ∑n∣En⟩⟨En∣ψ(0)⟩=∑ne−iEnt/ℏ∣En⟩⟨En∣ψ(0)⟩\begin{aligned}|\psi(t)\rangle &= e^{-i \widehat{B} t / \hbar} \sum_{n}\left|E_{n}\right\rangle\left\langle E_{n} | \psi(0)\right\rangle \\ &=\sum_{n} e^{-i E_{n} t / \hbar}\left|E_{n}\right\rangle\left\langle E_{n} | \psi(0)\right\rangle \end{aligned}∣ψ(t)⟩​=e−iBt/ℏn∑​∣En​⟩⟨En​∣ψ(0)⟩=n∑​e−iEn​t/ℏ∣En​⟩⟨En​∣ψ(0)⟩​

When the superposition involves states with different energies, the relative phase between the energy eigenstates changes with time. The time in this case satisfies

ΔEΔt≥ℏ2\Delta E \Delta t \geq \frac{\hbar}{2}ΔEΔt≥2ℏ​

where ∆𝐸 is the usual uncertainty in energy for the state ∣ψ⟩|\psi\rangle∣ψ⟩.

  • Suppose two stationary states,
Ψ1(x,t)=ψ1e−iω1t and Ψ2(x,t)=ψ2e−iω2t\Psi_{1}(x, t)=\psi_{1} e^{-i \omega_{1} t} \text { and } \Psi_{2}(x, t)=\psi_{2} e^{-i \omega_{2} t}Ψ1​(x,t)=ψ1​e−iω1​t and Ψ2​(x,t)=ψ2​e−iω2​t

where ℏω1=E1\hbar \omega_{1}=E_{1}ℏω1​=E1​ and ℏω2=E2\hbar \omega_{2}=E_{2}ℏω2​=E2​ are the corresponding energies.

To be definite, we could consider ψ1\psi_{1}ψ1​ and ψ2\psi_{2}ψ2​ to be the lowest two wave functions of the finite potential well with n=1 and 2. The linear combination of these two states,

Ψ(x,t)=c1Ψ1(x,t)+c2Ψ2(x,t)\Psi(x, t)=c_{1} \Psi_{1}(x, t)+c_{2} \Psi_{2}(x, t)Ψ(x,t)=c1​Ψ1​(x,t)+c2​Ψ2​(x,t)

for any two imaginary numbers c1c_{1}c1​ and c2c_{2}c2​.

  • In the time-dependent Schrodinger equation:
iℏ∂∂tΨ(x,t)=c1ℏ∂∂tΨ1(x,t)+c2ℏ∂∂tΨ2(x,t)=c1(−ℏ22m∂2∂x2+U(x))Ψ1(x,t)+c2(−ℏ22m∂2∂x2+U(x))Ψ2(x,t)=(−ℏ22m∂2∂x2+U(x))Ψ(x,t)\begin{aligned} i \hbar \frac{\partial}{\partial t} \Psi(x, t) &=c_{1} \hbar \frac{\partial}{\partial t} \Psi_{1}(x, t)+c_{2} \hbar \frac{\partial}{\partial t} \Psi_{2}(x, t) \\ &=c_{1}\left(-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial x^{2}}+U(x)\right) \Psi_{1}(x, t)+c_{2}\left(-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial x^{2}}+U(x)\right) \Psi_{2}(x, t) \\ &=\left(-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial x^{2}}+U(x)\right) \Psi(x, t) \end{aligned}iℏ∂t∂​Ψ(x,t)​=c1​ℏ∂t∂​Ψ1​(x,t)+c2​ℏ∂t∂​Ψ2​(x,t)=c1​(−2mℏ2​∂x2∂2​+U(x))Ψ1​(x,t)+c2​(−2mℏ2​∂x2∂2​+U(x))Ψ2​(x,t)=(−2mℏ2​∂x2∂2​+U(x))Ψ(x,t)​
  • The resulting state is not a stationary state.
Ψ(x,t)=c1ψ1(x)e−iω1t+c2ψ2(x)e−iω2t=e−iω1t[c1ψ1(x)+c2ψ2(x)e−iω′t]\begin{aligned} \Psi(x, t) &=c_{1} \psi_{1}(x) e^{-i \omega_{1} t}+c_{2} \psi_{2}(x) e^{-i \omega_{2} t} \\ &=e^{-i \omega_{1} t}\left[c_{1} \psi_{1}(x)+c_{2} \psi_{2}(x) e^{-i \omega^{\prime} t}\right] \end{aligned}Ψ(x,t)​=c1​ψ1​(x)e−iω1​t+c2​ψ2​(x)e−iω2​t=e−iω1​t[c1​ψ1​(x)+c2​ψ2​(x)e−iω′t]​

where ω′=ω2−ω1\omega^{\prime}=\omega_{2}-\omega_{1}ω′=ω2​−ω1​.

∣Ψ(x,t)∣2=∣c1ψ1(x)+c2ψ2(x)e−iω′t∣2|\Psi(x, t)|^{2}=\left|c_{1} \psi_{1}(x)+c_{2} \psi_{2}(x) e^{-i \omega^{\prime} t}\right|^{2}∣Ψ(x,t)∣2=∣∣∣​c1​ψ1​(x)+c2​ψ2​(x)e−iω′t∣∣∣​2

If c1c_{1}c1​ or c2c_{2}c2​ is not zero, this state is dependent of time. If c1c_{1}c1​ or c2c_{2}c2​ is zero, this state is stationary states.

  • If c1=c2=12c_{1}=c_{2}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}c1​=c2​=2​1​
∣Ψ(x,t)∣2=12∣ψ1(x)+ψ2(x)e−iω′t∣2=12∣ψ1(x)2+ψ2(x)2+2ψ1ψ2(x)cos⁡(ω′t)∣2\begin{aligned}|\Psi(x, t)|^{2} &=\frac{1}{2}\left|\psi_{1}(x)+\psi_{2}(x) e^{-i \omega^{\prime} t}\right|^{2} \\ &=\frac{1}{2}\left|\psi_{1}(x)^{2}+\psi_{2}(x)^{2}+2 \psi_{1} \psi_{2}(x) \cos \left(\omega^{\prime} t\right)\right|^{2} \end{aligned}∣Ψ(x,t)∣2​=21​∣∣∣​ψ1​(x)+ψ2​(x)e−iω′t∣∣∣​2=21​∣∣​ψ1​(x)2+ψ2​(x)2+2ψ1​ψ2​(x)cos(ω′t)∣∣​2​

where ω′=(E2−E1)ℏ\omega^{\prime}=\frac{\left(E_{2}-E_{1}\right)}{\hbar}ω′=ℏ(E2​−E1​)​

Because of the factor 𝑐𝑜𝑠(𝜔`𝑡), the probability density vary with time. In this case the time dependence is periodic, with period τ=2πω′\tau=\frac{2 \pi}{\omega^{\prime}}τ=ω′2π​. When the difference of energy of two states is increased, period(or ∆𝑡) is decreased.
